column2: IV
column3: i v

column2: GAMES AND SPORTS
column3: GAMES AND SPORTS

column2: The Indian boy was a prince of the wilderness.
column3: The Indian boy was a prince of the wilderness.

column2: He had but very little work to do during the period of his boyhood.
column3: He had but very little work to do during the period of his boyhood.

column2: His principal occupation was the practice of a few simple arts in warfare and the chase.
column3: His principal occupation was the practice of a few simple arts in warfare and the chase.

column2: Aside from this, he was master of his time.
column3: Aside from this, he was master of his time.

column2: It is true that our savage life was a precarious one, and full of dreadful catastrophes; however, this never prevented us from enjoying our sports to the fullest extent.
column3: It is true that our savage life was a precarious one, and full of dreadful catastrophes; however, this never prevented us from enjoying our sports to the fullest extent.

column2: As we left our teepees in the morning, we were never sure that our scalps would not dangle from a pole in the afternoon!
column3: As we left our teepees in the morning, we were never sure that our scalps would not dangle from a pole in the afternoon!

column2: It was an uncertain life, to be sure.
column3: It was an uncertain life, to be sure.

column2: Yet we observed that the fawns skipped and played happily while the gray wolves might be peeping forth from behind the hills, ready to tear them limb from limb.
column3: Yet we observed that the fawns skipped and played happily while the gray wolves might be peeping forth from behind the hills, ready to tear them limb from limb.

column2: Our sports were molded by the life and customs of our people; indeed, we practiced only what we expected to do when grown.
column3: Our sports were molded by the life and customs of our people; indeed, we practiced only what we expected to do when grown.

column2: Our games were feats with the bow and arrow, foot and pony races, wrestling, swimming and imitation of the customs and habits of our fathers.
column3: Our games were feats with the bow and arrow, foot and pony races, wrestling, swimming and imitation of the customs and habits of our fathers.

column2: We had sham fights with mud balls and willow wands; we played lacrosse, made war upon bees, shot winter arrows (which were used only in that season), and coasted upon the ribs of animals and buffalo robes.
column3: We had sham fights with mud balls and willow wands; we played lacrosse, made war upon bees, shot winter arrows (which were used only in that season), and coasted upon the ribs of animals and buffalo robes.

column2: No sooner did the boys get together than, as a usual thing, they divided into squads and chose sides; then a leading arrow was shot at random into the air.
column3: No sooner did the boys get together than, as a usual thing, they divided into squads and chose sides; then a leading arrow was shot at random into the air.

column2: Before it fell to the ground a volley from the bows of the participants followed.
column3: Before it fell to the ground a volley from the bows of the participants followed.

column2: Each player was quick to note the direction and speed of the leading arrow and he tried to send his own at the same speed and at an equal height, so that when it fell it would be closer to the first than any of the others.
column3: Each player was quick to note the direction and speed of the leading arrow and he tried to send his own at the same speed and at an equal height, so that when it fell it would be closer to the first than any of the others.

column2: It was considered out of place to shoot by first sighting the object aimed at.
column3: It was considered out of place to shoot by first sighting the object aimed at.

column2: This was usually impracticable in actual life, because the object was almost always in motion, while the hunter himself was often upon the back of a pony at full gallop.
column3: This was usually impracticable in actual life, because the object was almost always in motion, while the hunter himself was often upon the back of a pony at full gallop.

column2: Therefore, it was the off-hand shot that the Indian boy sought to master.
column3: Therefore, it was the off hand shot that the Indian boy sought to master.

column2: There was another game with arrows that was characterized by gambling, and was generally confined to the men.
column3: There was another game with arrows that was characterized by gambling, and was generally confined to the men.

column2: The races were an every-day occurrence.
column3: The races were an every day occurrence.

column2: At noon the boys were usually gathered by some pleasant sheet of water, and as soon as the ponies were watered, they were allowed to graze for an hour or two, while the boys stripped for their noonday sports.
column3: At noon the boys were usually gathered by some pleasant sheet of water, and as soon as the ponies were watered, they were allowed to graze for an hour or two, while the boys stripped for their noonday sports.

column2: A boy might say to some other whom he considered his equal:
column3: A boy might say to some other whom he considered his equal:

column2: I can't run; but I will challenge you to fifty paces.
column3: I can't run; but I will challenge you to fifty paces.

column2: A former hero, when beaten, would often explain his defeat by saying: "I drank too much water."
column3: A former hero, when beaten, would often explain his defeat by saying: "I drank too much water."

column2: Boys of all ages were paired for a "spin," and the little red men cheered on their favorites with spirit.
column3: Boys of all ages were paired for a "spin," and the little red men cheered on their favorites with spirit.

column2: As soon as this was ended, the pony races followed.
column3: As soon as this was ended, the pony races followed.

column2: All the speedy ponies were picked out and riders chosen.
column3: All the speedy ponies were picked out and riders chosen.

column2: If a boy declined to ride, there would be shouts of derision.
column3: If a boy declined to ride, there would be shouts of derision.

column2: Last of all came the swimming.
column3: Last of all came the swimming.

column2: A little urchin would hang to his pony's long tail, while the latter, with only his head above water, glided sportively along.
column3: A little urchin would hang to his pony's long tail, while the latter, with only his head above water, glided sportively along.

column2: Finally the animals were driven into a fine field of grass and we turned our attention to other games.
column3: Finally the animals were driven into a fine field of grass and we turned our attention to other games.

column2: The "mud-and-willow" fight was rather a severe and dangerous sport.
column3: The "mud and willow" fight was rather a severe and dangerous sport.

column2: A lump of soft clay was stuck on the end of a limber and springy willow wand and thrown as boys throw apples from sticks, with considerable force.
column3: A lump of soft clay was stuck on the end of a limber and springy willow wand and thrown as boys throw apples from sticks, with considerable force.

column2: When there were fifty or a hundred players on each side, the battle became warm; but anything to arouse the bravery of Indian boys seemed to them a good and wholesome diversion.
column3: When there were fifty or a hundred players on each side, the battle became warm; but anything to arouse the bravery of Indian boys seemed to them a good and wholesome diversion.

column2: Wrestling was largely indulged in by us all.
column3: Wrestling was largely indulged in by us all.

column2: It may seem odd, but wrestling was done by a great many boys at once--from ten to any number on a side.
column3: It may seem odd, but wrestling was done by a great many boys at once-from ten to any number on a side.

column2: It was really a battle, in which each one chose his opponent.
column3: It was really a battle, in which each one chose his opponent.

column2: The rule was that if a boy sat down, he was let alone, but as long as he remained standing within the field, he was open to an attack.
column3: The rule was that if a boy sat down, he was let alone, but as long as he remained standing within the field, he was open to an attack.

column2: No one struck with the hand, but all manner of tripping with legs and feet and butting with the knees was allowed.
column3: No one struck with the hand, but all manner of tripping with legs and feet and butting with the knees was allowed.

column2: Altogether it was an exhausting pastime--fully equal to the American game of football, and only the young athlete could really enjoy it.
column3: Altogether it was an exhausting pastime-fully equal to the American game of football, and only the young athlete could really enjoy it.

column2: One of our most curious sports was a war upon the nests of wild bees. We imagined ourselves about to make an attack upon the Ojibways or some tribal foe.
column3: One of our most curious sports was a war upon the nests of wild bees. We imagined ourselves about to make an attack upon the Ojibways or some tribal foe.

column2: We all painted and stole cautiously upon the nest; then, with a rush and war-whoop, sprang upon the object of our attack and endeavored to destroy it.
column3: We all painted and stole cautiously upon the nest; then, with a rush and war whoop, sprang upon the object of our attack and endeavored to destroy it.

column2: But it seemed that the bees were always on the alert and never entirely surprised, for they always raised quite as many scalps as did their bold assailants!
column3: But it seemed that the bees were always on the alert and never entirely surprised, for they always raised quite as many scalps as did their bold assailants!

column2: After the onslaught upon the nest was ended, we usually followed it by a pretended scalp dance.
column3: After the onslaught upon the nest was ended, we usually followed it by a pretended scalp dance.

column2: On the occasion of my first experience in this mode of warfare, there were two other little boys who were also novices.
column3: On the occasion of my first experience in this mode of warfare, there were two other little boys who were also novices.

column2: One of them particularly was really too young to indulge in an exploit of that kind.
column3: One of them particularly was really too young to indulge in an exploit of that kind.

column2: As it was the custom of our people, when they killed or wounded an enemy on the battle-field, to announce the act in a loud voice, we did the same.
column3: As it was the custom of our people, when they killed or wounded an enemy on the battle field, to announce the act in a loud voice, we did the same.

column2: My friend, Little Wound (as I will call him, for I do not remember his name), being quite small, was unable to reach the nest until it had been well trampled upon and broken and the insects had made a counter charge with such vigor as to repulse and scatter our numbers in every direction.
column3: My friend, Little Wound (as I will call him, for I do not remember his name), being quite small, was unable to reach the nest until it had been well trampled upon and broken and the insects had made a counter charge with such vigor as to repulse and scatter our numbers in every direction.

column2: However, he evidently did not want to retreat without any honors; so he bravely jumped upon the nest and yelled:
column3: However, he evidently did not want to retreat without any honors; so he bravely jumped upon the nest and yelled:

column2: I, the brave Little Wound, to-day kill the only fierce enemy!
column3: I, the brave Little Wound, to day kill the only fierce enemy!

column2: [Illustration: So he bravely jumped upon the nest.
column3: [Illustration: So he bravely jumped upon the nest.

column2: Scarcely were the last words uttered when he screamed as if stabbed to the heart.
column3: Scarcely were the last words uttered when he screamed as if stabbed to the heart.

column2: One of his older companions shouted:
column3: One of his older companions shouted:

column2: Dive into the water!	Dive into the water!
column3: true

column2: Run!
column3: Run!

column2: Dive into the water!" for there was a lake near by.
column3: Dive into the water!" for there was a lake near by.

column2: This advice he obeyed.
column3: This advice he obeyed.

column2: When we had reassembled and were indulging in our mimic dance, Little Wound was not allowed to dance.
column3: When we had reassembled and were indulging in our mimic dance, Little Wound was not allowed to dance.

column2: He was considered not to be in existence--he had been killed by our enemies, the Bee tribe.
column3: He was considered not to be in existence-he had been killed by our enemies, the Bee tribe.

column2: Poor little fellow!
column3: Poor little fellow!

column2: His swollen face was sad and ashamed as he sat on a fallen log and watched the dance.
column3: His swollen face was sad and ashamed as he sat on a fallen log and watched the dance.

column2: Although he might well have styled himself one of the noble dead who had died for their country, yet he was not unmindful that he had _screamed_, and this weakness would be apt to recur to him many times in the future.
column3: Although he might well have styled himself one of the noble dead who had died for their country, yet he was not unmindful that he had underscore screamed underscore, and this weakness would be apt to recur to him many times in the future.

column2: We had some quiet plays which we alternated with the more severe and warlike ones.
column3: We had some quiet plays which we alternated with the more severe and warlike ones.

column2: Among them were throwing wands and snow-arrows.
column3: Among them were throwing wands and snow arrows.

column2: In the winter we coasted much.
column3: In the winter we coasted much.

column2: We had no "double-rippers" or toboggans, but six or seven of the long ribs of a buffalo, fastened together at the larger end, answered all practical purposes.
column3: We had no "double rippers" or toboggans, but six or seven of the long ribs of a buffalo, fastened together at the larger end, answered all practical purposes.

column2: Sometimes a strip of bass-wood bark, four feet long and about six inches wide, was used with considerable skill.
column3: Sometimes a strip of bass wood bark, four feet long and about six inches wide, was used with considerable skill.

column2: We stood on one end and held the other, using the slippery inside of the bark for the outside, and thus coasting down long hills with remarkable speed.
column3: We stood on one end and held the other, using the slippery inside of the bark for the outside, and thus coasting down long hills with remarkable speed.

column2: The spinning of tops was one of the all-absorbing winter sports.
column3: The spinning of tops was one of the all absorbing winter sports.

column2: We made our tops heart-shaped of wood, horn or bone.
column3: We made our tops heart shaped of wood, horn or bone.

column2: We whipped them with a long thong of buckskin.
column3: We whipped them with a long thong of buckskin.

column2: The handle was a stick about a foot long and sometimes we whittled the stick to make it spoon-shaped at one end.
column3: The handle was a stick about a foot long and sometimes we whittled the stick to make it spoon shaped at one end.

column2: We played games with these tops--two to fifty boys at one time.
column3: We played games with these tops-two to fifty boys at one time.

column2: Each whips his top until it hums; then one takes the lead and the rest follow in a sort of obstacle race.
column3: Each whips his top until it hums; then one takes the lead and the rest follow in a sort of obstacle race.

column2: The top must spin all the way through.
column3: The top must spin all the way through.

column2: There were bars of snow over which we must pilot our top in the spoon end of our whip; then again we would toss it in the air on to another open spot of ice or smooth snow-crust from twenty to fifty paces away.
column3: There were bars of snow over which we must pilot our top in the spoon end of our whip; then again we would toss it in the air on to another open spot of ice or smooth snow crust from twenty to fifty paces away.

column2: The top that holds out the longest is the winner.
column3: The top that holds out the longest is the winner.

column2: We loved to play in the water.
column3: We loved to play in the water.

column2: When we had no ponies, we often had swimming matches of our own, and sometimes made rafts with which we crossed lakes and rivers.
column3: When we had no ponies, we often had swimming matches of our own, and sometimes made rafts with which we crossed lakes and rivers.

column2: It was a common thing to "duck" a young or timid boy or to carry him into deep water to struggle as best he might.
column3: It was a common thing to "duck" a young or timid boy or to carry him into deep water to struggle as best he might.

column2: I remember a perilous ride with a companion on an unmanageable log, when we were both less than seven years old.
column3: I remember a perilous ride with a companion on an unmanageable log, when we were both less than seven years old.

column2: The older boys had put us on this uncertain bark and pushed us out into the swift current of the river.
column3: The older boys had put us on this uncertain bark and pushed us out into the swift current of the river.

column2: I cannot speak for my comrade in distress, but I can say now that I would rather ride on a swift bronco any day than try to stay on and steady a short log in a river.
column3: I cannot speak for my comrade in distress, but I can say now that I would rather ride on a swift bronco any day than try to stay on and steady a short log in a river.

column2: I never knew how we managed to prevent a shipwreck on that voyage and to reach the shore.
column3: I never knew how we managed to prevent a shipwreck on that voyage and to reach the shore.

column2: We had many curious wild pets.
column3: We had many curious wild pets.

column2: There were young foxes, bears, wolves, raccoons, fawns, buffalo calves and birds of all kinds, tamed by various boys.
column3: There were young foxes, bears, wolves, raccoons, fawns, buffalo calves and birds of all kinds, tamed by various boys.

column2: My pets were different at different times, but I particularly remember one.
column3: My pets were different at different times, but I particularly remember one.

column2: I once had a grizzly bear for a pet, and so far as he and I were concerned, our relations were charming and very close.
column3: I once had a grizzly bear for a pet, and so far as he and I were concerned, our relations were charming and very close.

column2: But I hardly know whether he made more enemies for me or I for him.
column3: But I hardly know whether he made more enemies for me or I for him.

column2: It was his habit to treat every boy unmercifully who injured me.
column3: It was his habit to treat every boy unmercifully who injured me.

column2: V
column3: V

column2: AN INDIAN BOY'S TRAINING
column3: AN INDIAN BOY'S TRAINING

column2: Very early, the Indian boy assumed the task of preserving and transmitting the legends of his ancestors and his race.
column3: Very early, the Indian boy assumed the task of preserving and transmitting the legends of his ancestors and his race.

column2: Almost every evening a myth, or a true story of some deed done in the past, was narrated by one of the parents or grand-parents, while the boy listened with parted lips and glistening eyes.
column3: Almost every evening a myth, or a true story of some deed done in the past, was narrated by one of the parents or grand parents, while the boy listened with parted lips and glistening eyes.

column2: On the following evening, he was usually required to repeat it.
column3: On the following evening, he was usually required to repeat it.

column2: If he was not an apt scholar, he struggled long with his task; but, as a rule, the Indian boy is a good listener and has a good memory, so that the stories were tolerably well mastered.
column3: If he was not an apt scholar, he struggled long with his task; but, as a rule, the Indian boy is a good listener and has a good memory, so that the stories were tolerably well mastered.

column2: The household became his audience, by which he was alternately criticized and applauded.
column3: The household became his audience, by which he was alternately criticized and applauded.
